div.h1: Synthesis and characterization of fluorene derivatives as organic semiconductors for organic field-effect transistor

div.h2:
Abstract
Formulae display:
?
Mathematical formulae have been encoded as MathML and are displayed in this HTML version using MathJax in order to improve their display. Uncheck the box to turn MathJax off. This feature requires Javascript. Click on a formula to zoom.

div.p:
We have synthesized and characterized fluorene derivatives with alkylated thiophene as solution-processed organic semiconductors for organic field-effect transistor. HOMO/LUMO energy levels of the developed materials were tuned via different electron-acceptors. Organic field-effect transistor fabricated from dicyanovinylene-functionalized fluorine derivative with octyl thiophene as the side group exhibited n-channel characteristic with electron mobility of 0.0055âcm
2
/Vs and current on/off ratio â¼10
6
. Film surface morphology and texture were correlated with the corresponding device performance.
Keywords:

To this end, we have synthesized three new fluorene derivatives with alkylated thiophene units (
Fig. 1
). Acceptor moieties with carbonyl and dicyanovinylene functionalities were designed to decrease LUMO energy, which is important to achieve electron transport. Furthermore, alkylated thiophenes were employed as donor units with solution processability [
24
,
35
,
36
]. Thermal, electrochemical, and optical properties of the synthesized materials were investigated and density functional theory (DFT) calculation was used for the estimation of molecular structure of the corresponding compounds. In addition, we fabricated thin films of the organic materials via solution process on various substrates for bottom-gate/top-contact OFETs. Compound
4
was active as n-channel organic semiconductor with carrier mobility of 0.0055âcm
2
/Vs and current on/off ratio of 10
6
. Morphology and microstructure of the thin films analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and atomic force microscopy (AFM) were correlated with the corresponding device performance.

div.span: Synthesis and characterization of fluorene derivatives as organic semiconductors for organic field-effect transistor

div.div:
Kwanghee
Cho
,
M. Rajeshkumar
Reddy
,
Dongkyu
Kim
,
Dongil
Ho
,
Chaeyoung
Yun
,
SungYong
Seo
&
Choongik
Kim

div.p:
Figure 1.
Chemical structure of fluorene-based compounds
1â4
.

Figure 1.
Chemical structure of fluorene-based compounds
1â4
.

Reactions which are air and/or moisture sensitive were performed under an N
2
atmosphere in oven-dried glassware with anhydrous solvents. Unless otherwise noted, all compounds were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. 2,7-Diiodo-
9H
-fluoren-9-one, tributyl(5-(2-ethylhexyl)thiophen-2-yl)stannane (
1a
), and tributyl(5-octylthiophen-2-yl)stannane (
1b
) were synthesized according to the methods in the literatures [
37
,
38
]. Solvents were freshly distilled or dried by passing through an alumina column. General analysis method for the characterization of the synthesized compounds was described in previous work [
39
].

2,7-Diiodo-
9H
-fluoren-9-one (200âmg, 0.46âmmol), tributyl(5-(2-ethylhexyl)thiophen-2-yl)stannane
1a
(539âmg, 1.11âmmol), and Pd(dppf)Cl
2
(33âmg, 0.045âmmol) were dissolved in toluene (20âmL) and then solution temperature was increased to 110âÂ°C for 12âh under N
2
atmosphere. The reaction mixture was washed with water and brine using CH
2
Cl
2
and the solvent was removed in vacuo. Compound
1
was obtained through flash column chromatography on silica gel as red powder (150.2âmg, 57.0%).
1
H NMR (600âMHz, CDCl
3
):
Î´
7.83(d, 1.38âHz, 2H), 7.63 (dd, 2.04, 9.6âHz, 2H), 7.44 (d, 8.22âHz, 2H), 7.18 (d, 3.42âHz 2H), 6.72 (d, 3.42âHz, 2H), 2.74 (d, 6.90âHz, 4H), 1.56â1.60 (m, 2H), 1.28â1.40 (m, 16H), 0.88â0.89 (m, 12H).
13
C NMR (150âMHz, CDCl
3
):
Î´
193.6, 145.1, 142.3, 140.5, 135.6, 135.0, 131.1, 126.3, 123.2, 121.0, 120.6, 41.4, 34.1, 32.3, 28.8, 25.4, 22.9, 14.1, 10.8. HRMS-APCI(m/z): [M+] calcd. for C
37
H
44
OS
2
, 568.2834; found, 568.2837.

To a compound
1
(150âmg, 0.26âmmol) in DMSO, malanonitrile (0.5âmL) was added and then the reaction mixture was heated to 150âÂ°C for 12âh under N
2
atmosphere. To the reaction mixture, acetonitrile was poured and the precipitate was filtered washing with excess acetonitrile. Compound
2
was obtained as grayish green powder (120âmg, 73.8%).
1
H NMR (600âMHz, CDCl
3
):
Î´
8.57 (s, 2H), 7.61 (dd, 1.38, 8.22âHz, 2H), 7.44 (d, 8.28âHz, 2H), 7.20 (d, 3.48âHz, 2H), 6.72 (d, 3.48âHz, 2H), 2.73 (d, 6.84âHz, 4H), 1.56â1.60 (m, 2H), 1.26â1.38 (m, 16H), 0.87â0.89 (m, 12H).
13
C NMR (150âMHz, CDCl
3
):
Î´
160.9, 145.6, 140.0, 139.8, 135.5, 134.8, 130.7, 126.4, 123.6, 123.1, 120.7, 113.1, 76.2, 41.3, 34.2, 32.3, 28.8, 25.4, 23.0, 14.1, 10.7. HRMS-APCI(m/z): [M+] calcd. for C
40
H
44
N
2
S
2
, 616.2946; found, 616.2949.

Compound
3
was synthesized as red powder (95.1%) following the same procedure as compound
1
. Spectral data was matched with those in the literature [
42
].
1
H NMR (600âMHz, CDCl
3
):
Î´
7.83 (s, 2H), 7.63 (d, 8.22âHz, 2H), 7.44 (d, 7.56âHz, 2H), 7.17 (d, 3.42, 2H), 6.74 (d, 2.76âHz, 2H), 2.79â2.81 (m, 4H), 1.65â1.72 (m, 4H), 1.18â1.41 (m, 20H), 0.75â0.90 (m, 6H).

Density functional theory (DFT) calculations for energy optimization of the organic semiconductors were conducted through the B3LYP (Beckeâs three parameters employing the Lee-Yang-Parr) method and the 6-31G(d) basis set as implemented in Gaussian 03W program.

To investigate the field-effect properties of the compounds
1
,
2
,
3,
and
4
, bottom-gate/top-contact OFETs were fabricated by drop-casting semiconductor solution on n
++
âSi/SiO
2
(300ânm) gate-dielectric substrates. The Si/SiO
2
substrates were sonicated in acetone and isopropyl alcohol for 10âmin each, blown with N
2
gas, followed by air plasma treatment for 5âmin (Harrick Plasma, 18W). Then, the surfaces of the SiO
2
were treated with PTS (phenyl trichlorosilane) or PS-brush [
43
,
44
]. Drop-casting method was employed for the formation of the organic semiconductor layer. The drop-casted substrates were annealed in a vacuum oven at 100âÂ°C for 2âh. The concentration of the semiconductor solution (1â4âmg/mL), solvent type (chloroform, toluene), and substrate temperature (60â80% of the solvent boiling point) were varied for the optimization of film-forming process and enhanced device performance. Film thicknesses were measured by profilometer (DEKTAK-XT, Brucker) as 270â300ânm. Gold source and drain (40ânm thickness) electrodes were thermally evaporated at rate of 0.2 Ã /s using a shadow mask with channel length and width of 50 and 500 Âµm, respectively.

Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA, TA Instrument Q50-1555) were performed on each sample in a platinum pan. Specifically, the temperature for TGA were ramped from 40 to 800âÂ°C at a rate of 10âÂ°C/min under N
2
atmosphere. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC, TA instrument Q20-2487) analyses were conducted from 45 to 200âÂ°C at a rate of 10âÂ°C/min. UV-vis (JASCO V-530) absorption spectra of the compounds were scanned over the spectral range of 200â800ânm in dilute chloroform solution and as spin-coated thin films. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) experiments were carried out with three electrodes (Ag/AgCl reference electrode, carbon working electrode, and platinum counter electrode) in dichloromethane using electrochemical analyser/workstation (CHI 900D, CH Instruments, Inc.). All the electrochemical potentials were referenced with ferrocenium/ferrocene internal standard.

The current-voltage characteristics of the fabricated OFETs were measured on a Keithley 4200 SCS at room temperature under vacuum. The saturation mobility (
Âµ
sat
) was calculated by the following formula:
Î¼
sat
=
(
2
I
DS
L
)
/
[
WC
i
(
V
G
â
V
T
)
2
]
where
I
DS
is the source-drain current,
L
is the channel length,
W
is the channel width,
C
i
is the dielectric capacitance (10.9 nF/cm
2
),
V
G
is the gate voltage, and
V
T
is the threshold voltage. Surface morphology and microstructure of organic thin film were analyzed by atomic force microscope (AFM, NX10, park Systems) and X-ray diffraction (XRD, MAX-2500), respectively.

Stille coupling of 2,7-diiodo-
9H
-fluoren-9-one with suitable tin compounds
1a
and
1b
afforded 2,7-bis(5-(2-ethylhexyl)thiophen-2-yl)-
9H
-fluoren-9-one (
1
) and 2,7-bis(5-octylthiophen-2-yl)-
9H
-fluoren-9-one (
3
), as shown in
Scheme 1
[40]. Also, 2-(2,7-bis(5-(2-ethylhexyl)thiophen-2-yl)-
9H
-fluoren-9-ylidene)malononitrile (
2
) and 2-(2,7-bis(5-octylthiophen-2-yl)-
9H
-fluoren-9-ylidene)malononitrile (
4
) were obtained using malononitrile, as shown in
Scheme 1
[
45
].

div.span: Synthesis and characterization of fluorene derivatives as organic semiconductors for organic field-effect transistor

div.div:
Kwanghee
Cho
,
M. Rajeshkumar
Reddy
,
Dongkyu
Kim
,
Dongil
Ho
,
Chaeyoung
Yun
,
SungYong
Seo
&
Choongik
Kim

div.p:
Scheme 1.
Synthetic scheme of compounds
1
,
2
,
3,
and
4
.

Scheme 1.
Synthetic scheme of compounds
1
,
2
,
3,
and
4
.

Density functional theory (DFT) calculations for the compounds were conducted to determine molecular structure and HOMO/LUMO energy using B3LYP method and 6-31G basis set by Gaussian 03W program. As shown in
Fig. 2
, HOMO/LUMO energy levels of all the compounds were distributed on the main backbone and fluorene derivative moiety, respectively. The calculated HOMO/LUMO energy levels of compounds
1
,
2
, and
4
were â5.16/â2.17, â5.29/â3.20, and â5.29/â3.19âeV, respectively (
Fig. 2
). Furthermore, energy bandgap of the compounds
1
,
2
, and
4
were 2.99, 2.09, and 2.10âeV, respectively. Strong electron-accepting ability of dicyanovinylene compared to carbonyl group afforded lower LUMO level for compounds
2
and
4
than compound
1
. Although the DFT calculations did not give exact HOMO/LUMO levels, they were used for identifying energy level trends based on ionization potential of the donor and electron affinity of the acceptor [
46
].

div.span: Synthesis and characterization of fluorene derivatives as organic semiconductors for organic field-effect transistor

div.div:
Kwanghee
Cho
,
M. Rajeshkumar
Reddy
,
Dongkyu
Kim
,
Dongil
Ho
,
Chaeyoung
Yun
,
SungYong
Seo
&
Choongik
Kim

div.p:
Figure 2.
Molecular orbital and HOMO/LUMO energy levels of compounds
1â4
. Solid lines and dash lines are HOMO/LUMO energy levels determined by DFT calculation and cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement, respectively.

Figure 2.
Molecular orbital and HOMO/LUMO energy levels of compounds
1â4
. Solid lines and dash lines are HOMO/LUMO energy levels determined by DFT calculation and cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement, respectively.

Thermal properties of the synthesized compounds were investigated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) (
Table 1
). As shown in
Table 1
, the synthesized compounds
1
,
2
,
3,
and
4
were found to be thermally stable with thermolysis onset temperatures (5% weight loss) of 265âÂ°C, 387âÂ°C, 372âÂ°C, and 290âÂ°C, respectively. In addition, DSC measurements indicate endotherms (melting point) at 80, 75, 120, and 130âÂ°C for compounds
1
,
2
,
3
, and
4
, respectively. Compounds
3
and
4
exhibited higher melting point than compounds
1
and
2
, which might be ascribed to enhanced solid-state packing of compound
4
with linear alkyl side chains. Branched alkyl chains of compounds
1
and
2
might deteriorate the intermolecular interactions and contribute relatively poor solid-state packing.

div.span: Synthesis and characterization of fluorene derivatives as organic semiconductors for organic field-effect transistor

div.div:
Kwanghee

,

h3.p:
Table 1.
Thermal, optical and electrochemical properties of the compounds
1â4
.

div.p:
The optical absorption spectra of the compounds in dilute chloroform and as spin-coated thin film are shown in
Fig. 3
. At short wavelengths (<400ânm), intense absorption peaks corresponding to the
Ï
â
Ï
* transition of the fluorene derivatives were observed. The low absorption peaks at 480 and 450ânm (for compound
1
and compound
3
) and 620ânm (for compound
2
and
4
) resulted from
n
â
Ï
* transitions by the presence of carbonyl/dicyanovinylene groups [
5
]. Dicyanovinylene substitution exhibited significant red shift of â¼181ânm in the low-energy absorption region, which shows that LUMO energy level of compounds
2
and
4
was stabilized due to the strong electron-withdrawing ability of dicyanovinylene group. The energy band gaps estimated from the onset of the experimental optical absorption were 2.20âeV for compound
1
, 1.67âeV for compound
2
, 2.45âeV for compound
3
, and 1.70âeV for compound
4
(
Table 1
), respectively.

1â4
in dilute chloroform solution.

1â4
in dilute chloroform solution.

div.span: Synthesis and characterization of fluorene derivatives as organic semiconductors for organic field-effect transistor

div.div:
Kwanghee
Cho
,
M. Rajeshkumar
Reddy
,
Dongkyu

,
Dongil
Ho
,

,

&

div.p:
Figure 4.
Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement of the compounds
1â4
in dichloromethane.

Figure 4.
Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement of the compounds
1â4
in dichloromethane.

HOMO/LUMO energy levels of the compounds were further estimated in dichloromethane at room temperature by cyclic voltammetry (CV)(Fig. 4). The HOMO and LUMO energy levels (
E
HOMO
,
E
LUMO
) were estimated using the following formula.
(1)
ELOMO
(
eV
)
=
â
e
(
E
red
onset
-
E
Fc
/
Fc
+
onset
)
â
4.80
eV
(1)
(2)
EHOMO
(
eV
)
=
â
e
(
E
ox
onset
-
E
Fc
/
Fc
+
onset
)
â
4.80
eV
(2)
where
E
ox
onset
is the potential of the oxidation process,
E
red
onset
is the potential of the reduction process, and
E
Fc
/
Fc
+
onset
is the intermediate potential of
F
C
/
F
C
+
between the two onset points of the peaks. The electrochemically-determined energy bad gap of compounds
1
,
2
,
3
, and
4
were 2.22, 1.74, 2.20, and 1.82âeV, respectively (
Table 1
). Lower LUMO energy level of compounds
2
and
4
with strong electron-accepting dicyanovinylene group afforded smaller energy gaps compared to compounds
1
and
3.

Bottom-gate/top-contact OFETs were fabricated to investigate the synthesized compounds as organic semiconductors. Semiconductor films were formed by drop-casting onto Si/SiO
2
substrate treated with PTS as dielectric. For drop-casting process, various conditions including solvent, concentration, and substrate temperature were optimized. Among developed compounds, thin films of compound
4
drop-casted at 70âÂ°C substrate from toluene solution only exhibited n-channel device characteristics with maximum electron mobility of 0.0055âcm
2
/Vs and a current on/off ratio of about 10
6
under vacuum (
Fig. 5
, Supplemental Table S1). It is probably because of the higher n-type conductivity of fluorene derivatives with dicyanovinylene group than fluorene derivatives with carbonyl group [
34
].

div.span: Synthesis and characterization of fluorene derivatives as organic semiconductors for organic field-effect transistor

div.div:
Kwanghee
Cho
,
M. Rajeshkumar
Reddy
,
Dongkyu
Kim
,
Dongil
Ho
,
Chaeyoung
Yun
,
SungYong
Seo
&
Choongik
Kim

div.p:
Figure 5.
Electrical characterization of organic field-effect transistor fabricated with compound
4
on PTS-treated Si/SiO
2
substrate.

Figure 5.
Electrical characterization of organic field-effect transistor fabricated with compound
4
on PTS-treated Si/SiO
2
substrate.

Surface morphology and film microstructure of the drop-casted films were characterized with
Î¸
-2
Î¸
XRD and AFM to assess device performance. As shown in
Fig. 6A
, thin films of compounds
1â3
did not show any peaks, indicating poor film texture. On the other hand, thin film of compound
4
exhibited several diffraction peaks up to fifth-order, which indicate highly crystalline microstructure of the thin films. Among them, the major primary peak was shown at 2
Î¸
=â3.40Â°, corresponding to d-spacing of 2.6ânm. The d-spacing is smaller than computed molecular length of 3.2ânm. This means that alkyl chains might be interdigitated with tilted molecular orientation on the substrate.

div.span: Synthesis and characterization of fluorene derivatives as organic semiconductors for organic field-effect transistor

div.div:
Kwanghee
Cho
,
M. Rajeshkumar
Reddy
,
Dongkyu
Kim
,
Dongil
Ho
,
Chaeyoung
Yun
,
SungYong
Seo
&
Choongik
Kim

div.p:
Figure 6.
(A)
Î¸
-2
Î¸
XRD scan for thin films of compounds
1
â
4
and (B) AFM topographic images of films fabricated by drop-casting of compound
4
. Scale bars indicate 1 Âµm.

Figure 6.
(A)
Î¸
-2
Î¸
XRD scan for thin films of compounds
1
â
4
and (B) AFM topographic images of films fabricated by drop-casting of compound
4
. Scale bars indicate 1 Âµm.

AFM characterization of drop-casted films of compounds
1â4
are shown in
Fig. 6
and Supplemental Figure S1. As shown in
Fig. 6B
, thin films of compound
4
exhibited large, terraced film morphology. The step heights of compound
4
were 2.5â2.6ânm, corresponding to d-spacing value estimated from the XRD characterization. On the other hand, drop-casted films of compounds
1
and
2
show island-like morphologies with relatively large area of voids.

In this study, we synthesized and characterized fluorene derivatives as solution-processed organic semiconductors for OFET. Thin films of compound
4
showed crystalline films with favorable morphology for charge transport, and the highest electron mobility of 0.0055âcm
2
/Vs and current on/off ratio of â¼10
6
were observed. Our work suggests that fluorine moiety with appropriate functional groups could be attractive building blocks for novel organic semiconductors for various applications.

Table 1.
Thermal, optical and electrochemical properties of the compounds
1â4
.

a
Five percent decomposition temperature measured by TGA.

b
Melting temperature measured by DSC.

c

d
Optical band gap estimated from onset of the optical absorption.

e
Measured in 1.0 M tetrabutylammonium tetrafluoroborate solution in dichloromethane using an Ag/Ag
+
reference electrode and Pt working electrode.

f
Calculated from the
Eq. (1)
.

g
Calculated from the
Eq. (2)
.

h

E
g
=
E
LUMO
â
E
HOMO
.

div.p:
People also read
lists articles that other readers of this article have read.

Recommended articles
lists articles that we recommend and is powered by our AI driven recommendation engine.

Cited by
lists all citing articles based on Crossref citations.
Articles with the Crossref icon will open in a new tab.
